trans-unit.source: Represents an X.509 store, which is a physical store where certificates are persisted and managed.
This class cannot be inherited.
Use this class to work with an X.509 store.
Starting with the [!INCLUDE[net_v46](~/includes/net-v46-md.md)], this type implements the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface.
When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly.
To dispose of the type directly, call its <xref:System.IDisposable.Dispose%2A> method in a `try`/`catch` block.
To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as `using` (in C#) or `Using` (in Visual Basic).
For more information, see the "Using an Object that Implements IDisposable" section in the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface topic.

For apps that target the [!INCLUDE[net_v452](~/includes/net-v452-md.md)] and earlier versions, the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> class does not implement the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface and therefore does not have a `Dispose` method.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using the personal certificates of the current user store.
Use this constructor to create an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> object using the personal X.509 certificate store for the current user.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using an Intptr handle to an `HCERTSTORE` store.
Use this constructor to provide compatibility with the unmanaged Microsoft Cryptographic API (CAPI).
For more information about the `HCERTSTORE` handle, see the unmanaged CAPI documentation in the Platform SDK section of the [MSDN Library](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37118).
A handle to an `HCERTSTORE` store.
The storeHandle parameter is `null`.
The storeHandle parameter points to an invalid context.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using the specified <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreLocation"></xref> value.

Use this constructor to create an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> object, specifying the store location, which is either the location for the current user or the local computer.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the location of the X.509 certificate store.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using the specified <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName"></xref> value.
Use this constructor to create an X.509 store for the current user that corresponds to values enumerated by <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName>.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the name of the X.509 certificate store.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using the specified store name.
Use this constructor to create an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> object using a particular X.509 store name for the current user.
To create a new store, specify a name that does not exist.
A new store will be created with that name.
A string value that represents the store name.
See <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName"></xref> for more information.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using the specified <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName"></xref> and <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreLocation"></xref> values.
Use this constructor to create an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> object, specifying both the store name and the store location.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the name of the X.509 certificate store.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the location of the X.509 certificate store.
storeLocation is not a valid location or storeName is not a valid name.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref> class using a string that represents a value from the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName"></xref> enumeration and a value from the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreLocation"></xref> enumeration.
Use this constructor to create an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> object using a store name and location.
To create a new store, specify a name that does not exist.
A new store will be created with that name.
A string that represents a value from the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName"></xref> enumeration.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the location of the X.509 certificate store.
storeLocation contains invalid values.
Adds a certificate to an X.509 certificate store.
Use this method to add a single certificate to an X.509 store.
The certificate to add.
certificate is `null`.
The certificate could not be added to the store.
Adds a collection of certificates to an X.509 certificate store.
This method adds more than one certificate to an X.509 certificate store; if one certificate addition fails, the operation is reverted and no certificates are added.
The collection of certificates to add.
certificates is `null`.
The caller does not have the required permission.
Returns a collection of certificates located in an X.509 certificate store.
This method returns a snapshot of the X.509 certificate store.

Note that subsequent <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store.Add%2A> or <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store.Remove%2A> operations performed on the store will not have any effect on the collection that is returned.
This snapshot is recalculated each time the property is called, so the use of this property inside an iterative function is not recommended.
A collection of certificates.
Closes an X.509 certificate store.
This method releases all resources associated with the store.
You should always close an X.509 certificate store after use.
Releases the resources used by this <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store"></xref>.

<xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> implements the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface starting with the [!INCLUDE[net_v46](~/includes/net-v46-md.md)]; in previous versions of the .NET Framework, the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store> class does not implement this interface, and therefore the `Dispose` method does not exist.
Gets the location of the X.509 certificate store.
This property returns the X.509 certificate store location of either the store for the current user or the store for the local computer.
The location of the certificate store.
Gets the name of the X.509 certificate store.
This property returns the X.509 certificate store name.
This value can indicate the type of certificates stored, such as root certificates or certificates from trusted publishers.
The name of the certificate store.
Opens an X.509 certificate store or creates a new store, depending on <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags"></xref> flag settings.
Use this method to open an existing X.509 store.
Note that you must have additional permissions, specified by <xref:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags>, to enumerate the certificates in the store.

You can create a new store by passing a store name that does not exist to the class constructor, and then using any of the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags> flags except <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags.OpenExistingOnly>.
A bitwise combination of enumeration values that specifies the way to open the X.509 certificate store.
The store is unreadable.
The caller does not have the required permission.
The store contains invalid values.
Removes a certificate from an X.509 certificate store.
Use this method to remove a single certificate from an X.509 store.
The certificate to remove.
certificate is `null`.
The caller does not have the required permission.
Removes a range of certificates from an X.509 certificate store.
This type implements the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface.
When you have finished using the type, you should dispose of it either directly or indirectly.
To dispose of the type directly, call its <xref:System.IDisposable.Dispose%2A> method in a `try`/`catch` block.
To dispose of it indirectly, use a language construct such as `using` (in C#) or `Using` (in Visual Basic).
For more information, see the "Using an Object that Implements IDisposable" section in the <xref:System.IDisposable> interface topic.
This method removes more than one certificate from an X.509 certificate store; if one certificate removal fails, the operation is reverted and no certificates are removed.
A range of certificates to remove.
certificates is `null`.
The caller does not have the required permission.
Gets an <xref href="System.IntPtr"></xref> handle to an `HCERTSTORE` store.
Use the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store.StoreHandle%2A> property to provide compatibility with the unmanaged Microsoft Cryptographic API (CAPI).
For more information about the `HCERTSTORE` handle, see the unmanaged CAPI documentation in the Platform SDK section of the [MSDN Library](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37118).
A handle to an `HCERTSTORE` store.
The store is not open.
